sections.title: Conservative-first TMJ disorder treatment
sections.body: We assess joint sounds, range, and muscle tension to understand your TMJ symptoms. Care focuses on reversible measures, protection, and referral when specialist input is needed.
bullets: Comprehensive assessment of joint movement, bite, and muscle patterns
Self-care, guards, and physiotherapy pathways before invasive options
Clear safety netting with guidance on when urgent care is required

sections.title: Evidence-based and escalation-aware
items: Assessment includes joint noises, deviation, locking episodes, and pain mapping
We review previous trauma, orthodontics, and occlusal changes that affect the TMJ
Physiotherapy and medical colleagues involved early when indicated
Urgent pathways explained for sudden locking, swelling, or suspected infection

sections.title: Listen, examine, and tailor care
sections.body: Your clinician reviews symptoms, examines joint range and clicks, and checks bite stability. Imaging or referral is arranged when findings suggest structural change. We co-create a plan that starts conservatively and respects your comfort.
bullets: History of locking, noise, and pain episodes
Examination of opening range, deviations, and muscle tenderness
Guard options, bite adjustments, and stretching protocols explained
When therapeutic injectables may support muscle-related symptoms
Referral letters for imaging or specialist TMJ clinics if required

sections.title: Patients with TMJ-related symptoms
items: Clicking or popping joints with or without pain
Intermittent locking or stiffness when opening wide
Jaw fatigue or headaches linked to chewing or clenching
Existing dental work needing protection during TMJ care
Patients wanting a clear conservative plan before invasive routes

sections.title: Staged, conservative-first TMJ care
items: Assessment and diagnosis with documentation of joint findings
Self-care guidance and habit coaching to reduce strain
Custom guards or occlusal adjustments when indicated
Therapeutic injectables for muscle overactivity if clinically suitable
Referral for imaging, physiotherapy, or TMJ specialist input when needed
Review and maintenance to track stability
sections.strapline: We keep interventions reversible where possible and explain when further medical investigation is recommended.

sections.title: Protect your joints and know when to escalate
items: Follow stretching, posture, and guard guidance consistently
Avoid overloading the joint during flare-ups; use soft diets if advised
Report new locking, swelling, or altered bite promptly
Seek urgent care if you cannot open, have spreading swelling, or fever

sections.title: Joined-up jaw care
items: Bruxism and jaw clenching support to reduce overloading (/treatments/bruxism-and-jaw-clenching)
Facial pain and headache assessment to address linked symptoms (/treatments/facial-pain-and-headache)
Therapeutic facial injectables for selected muscle-related cases (/treatments/therapeutic-facial-injectables)
Night guards (occlusal splints) for joint protection when indicated (/treatments/night-guards-occlusal-splints)

faqs.question: Do I always need imaging?
faqs.answer: No. Imaging is recommended when symptoms, history, or examination suggest structural joint changes or atypical findings.

faqs.question: Will exercises alone help?
faqs.answer: Exercises and habit change often improve symptoms. Guards, adjustments, or medicines are considered when exercises are insufficient or risk of damage is present.

faqs.question: What if my jaw locks?
faqs.answer: Intermittent locking is assessed in clinic. Sudden inability to open or close, severe pain, or swelling warrants urgent contact or emergency care.

faqs.question: Are injectables used for TMJ disorders?
faqs.answer: Only in selected cases after conservative steps. Doses are tailored to relieve muscle overactivity rather than cosmetic aims.

faqs.question: How long does treatment take?
faqs.answer: Timelines vary; we review progress regularly and adjust the plan based on symptoms, guard wear, and any specialist feedback.

sections.title: Book a TMJ disorder assessment
sections.body: Discuss locking, clicking, or jaw pain with a clinician who prioritises reversible care and clear escalation pathways.
